Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to address the jury. It was a text from Jamie: “Rough day. Everything feels pointless. Can you talk?” I knew Jamie needed me—he’d been having a hard time lately, and I’d promised to be there, to listen, to help him feel less alone. But at that exact moment, my clerk hurried over, eyes wide, and handed me a note: the Supreme Court had just overturned the precedent my entire jury instruction was based on. I felt my heart race. As a judge, I was expected to be up-to-the-minute on the law, to ensure justice was served, and now I had to halt everything, review the new ruling, and possibly rewrite my instructions on the spot. My friend needed comfort, but the courtroom demanded my full attention and expertise. I stared at my phone, then at the anxious faces in the jury box, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which voice to answer first.
